title: Successes, Failures and Learning From Them

Let me summarize on some of the things I think we do best and worse.
Number one is kind of a nerdy geeky detail.
We a lot of times take shortcuts with our data.
We dive in and we look at all the data and we don't properly reserve some.
We make some judgments based on an overall survey of the data, and that judgment creeps into our cross validation studies and so forth over and over.
We work with clients who have thought they had better results than they really do when they, when they do this very carefully and scientifically.
So I think a lot of learning on how to do the data accounting.
In our in our studies would be very helpful.
We tend to look ahead more than we think we are.
I think as an industry and as a conference, we focus on algorithms too much.
Now that is the fun stuff.
And that's what I love.
But we really need to pay attention to the whole ecosystem that allows our craft to thrive and it pay more attention to the process.

There's an interactive, interactive and iterative development of that score function which drives everything.
Because if one solution is preferable to the other, we want the interests of the computer in the human to be as much as in line as possible.
Lastly, as as all the other speakers have said, we have something that's endangering the very existence of our field and that is improperly handling privacy and data security issues.
We really need technological an social awareness of what we're doing with the data and what the dangers are and what would happen.
We were going to do great things with the data, and we're going to take great care of it.
But what happens if our laptop is stolen?

That's happened over and over, and each of those things get in the news and people we have to help have to go before Congress and defend themselves or whoever you know it just we could have connected the dots before 911 and and yet the political pendulum swung all the way from saying.
Let's do more data mining to protect ourselves and law abiding citizens all the way to saying data mining is a danger and so if we don't pay attention to anonymizing data and.

And it has to be more than just shuffling the randomizing the ID codes for a person, because apparently there's some interesting research that from a date of birth and zip code you can identify uniquely half of Americans and things like that, so few clues and you can put together as Jon Kleinberg, I think mentioned two you can identify folks in the network, so that's a very, very important issue in it.
It's a force that's bigger than our field that can crush us if we don't handle it well.
Now on to the happy side.

I think one of the big successes over the years where data mining is really paid off has been scoring things like credit scoring, fraud detection, being able to prioritize a very valuable workers time.

Being able to sort the things that they're looking at so that the needle in the haystack problem you have higher proportion of needles where they're spending their time and again harnessing that human intuition and expertise, which is very hard to capture mechanically.
So I see data mining as an EXO skeleton.
That a person puts on to strengthen them to strengthen their their power, sometimes tenfold or more, but not to replace.
It's not a robot that replaces a person in most of the things we work in.
Another fun thing is the software tools getting better and better.
Now there's a long way to go.
I think we're at the stage where we have the equivalent of seatbelts now in a car, you know, and we need those airbags.

But the tools I've really it's a competitive environment.

We should keep giving feedback.

I think another great thing is the wide acceptance of the recommendation systems.
Even a little bit of help there seems to be very appreciated by consumers and all of us since this made life more convenient.
Lastly, of course I think one of the biggest things is ensembles.
